+              objects are stored in the Java heap space until processing

+              This occurs because equality is determined by the equivalence of
+              the resulting bytes[] instead of the object instances.

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,87 @@
+[id='how_eviction_works-{context}']
+= How Eviction Works
+{brandname} eviction relies on two configurations:
+
+* Size of the data container.
+* Eviction strategy.
+
+.Calculating data container size
+
+You configure the maximum size of the data container and specify if {brandname}
+stores cache entries as:
+
+* Object in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in native memory (off-heap).

nodes.bodyText:
It doesn't iterate, it just keeps a running counter as entries are inserted or removed.
I don't know if we need to mention this part tbh.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,87 @@
+[id='how_eviction_works-{context}']
+= How Eviction Works
+{brandname} eviction relies on two configurations:
+
+* Size of the data container.
+* Eviction strategy.
+
+.Calculating data container size
+
+You configure the maximum size of the data container and specify if {brandname}
+stores cache entries as:
+
+* Object in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in native memory (off-heap).
+
+|===
+| Storage type | Size of the data container is calculated as:
+
+| Object
+| Number of entries.
+
+| Binary
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+
+| Off-heap
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+|===
+
+To calculate the data container size, {brandname} does one of the following:
+
+* Iterates over caches to count the number of entries to determine size.

nodes.bodyText: I am not sure if we want to put %'s here as this can change as JVMs improve.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,87 @@
+[id='how_eviction_works-{context}']
+= How Eviction Works
+{brandname} eviction relies on two configurations:
+
+* Size of the data container.
+* Eviction strategy.
+
+.Calculating data container size
+
+You configure the maximum size of the data container and specify if {brandname}
+stores cache entries as:
+
+* Object in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in native memory (off-heap).
+
+|===
+| Storage type | Size of the data container is calculated as:
+
+| Object
+| Number of entries.
+
+| Binary
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+
+| Off-heap
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+|===
+
+To calculate the data container size, {brandname} does one of the following:
+
+* Iterates over caches to count the number of entries to determine size.
+* Takes the size of each `byte[]` and includes the overhead of object pointers to determine size.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+When using `MEMORY`, {brandname} can determine only an approximate size of data containers. For the HotSpot JVM, {brandname} can calculate an approximate size within 3% of the actual size. For other JVMs, the calculation can be within 10%.

nodes.bodyText: Same here, we may want to just mention that it is a closer approximation that the on heap ones possibly.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,87 @@
+[id='how_eviction_works-{context}']
+= How Eviction Works
+{brandname} eviction relies on two configurations:
+
+* Size of the data container.
+* Eviction strategy.
+
+.Calculating data container size
+
+You configure the maximum size of the data container and specify if {brandname}
+stores cache entries as:
+
+* Object in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in native memory (off-heap).
+
+|===
+| Storage type | Size of the data container is calculated as:
+
+| Object
+| Number of entries.
+
+| Binary
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+
+| Off-heap
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+|===
+
+To calculate the data container size, {brandname} does one of the following:
+
+* Iterates over caches to count the number of entries to determine size.
+* Takes the size of each `byte[]` and includes the overhead of object pointers to determine size.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+When using `MEMORY`, {brandname} can determine only an approximate size of data containers. For the HotSpot JVM, {brandname} can calculate an approximate size within 3% of the actual size. For other JVMs, the calculation can be within 10%.
+
+When using `MEMORY` with off-heap storage, the calculation is more precise and typically within 1% of the actual size.

nodes.bodyText: Maybe something more along the lines of "When an entry is added or modified in the {brandname} data container, it compares the current eviction size with the maximum and if the current exceeds the maximum, {brandname} evicts entries. You can play with the wording obviously.

+
+You configure the maximum size of the data container and specify if {brandname}
+stores cache entries as:
+
+* Object in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in the Java heap.
+* Binary `byte[]` in native memory (off-heap).
+
+|===
+| Storage type | Size of the data container is calculated as:
+
+| Object
+| Number of entries.
+
+| Binary
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+
+| Off-heap
+| Number of entries, if the eviction type is `COUNT`. +
+Amount of memory, in bytes, if the eviction type is `MEMORY`.
+|===
+
+To calculate the data container size, {brandname} does one of the following:
+
+* Iterates over caches to count the number of entries to determine size.
+* Takes the size of each `byte[]` and includes the overhead of object pointers to determine size.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+When using `MEMORY`, {brandname} can determine only an approximate size of data containers. For the HotSpot JVM, {brandname} can calculate an approximate size within 3% of the actual size. For other JVMs, the calculation can be within 10%.
+
+When using `MEMORY` with off-heap storage, the calculation is more precise and typically within 1% of the actual size.
+====
+
+.Evicting cache entries

nodes.bodyText: Technically it is if a given object would put it over 100 bytes. For example if you had 95 bytes in use and a new object would add another 40, then it would have to evict one or more to make room. MEMORY based eviction is special in that it can actually evict more than one entry for a single put operation.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,96 @@
+[id='eviction_example-{context}']
+= Eviction Example
+
+You configure eviction in `infinispan.xml` as part of your cache definition.
+
+.Default memory configuration
+
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<memory />
+----
+
+This is the default configuration. {brandname} stores cache entries as objects
+in the data container. Eviction is not enabled.
+
+.Passivation without eviction
+
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<persistence passivation="true">
+  ...
+</persistence>
+
+<memory />
+----
+
+This configuration is not valid and {brandname} writes an error to log files.
+
+Passivation configures {brandname} to write entries to cache stores when it
+evicts those entries. You should always enable eviction if you enable
+passivation.
+
+.Manual eviction
+
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<memory>
+  <object strategy="MANUAL" />
+</memory>
+----
+
+{brandname} stores cache entries as objects. Eviction is not enabled but
+performed manually using the `evict()` method. In this case, {brandname} does
+not log errors if you enable passivation.
+
+.Object storage with eviction
+
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<memory>
+  <object size="100" />
+</memory>
+----
+
+{brandname} stores cache entries as objects. Eviction happens when there are
+100 entries in the data container and {brandname} gets a request to create a
+new entry.
+
+.Binary storage with memory-based eviction
+
+[source,xml,options="nowrap",subs=attributes+]
+----
+<memory>
+  <binary size="100" eviction="MEMORY"/>
+</memory>
+----
+
+{brandname} stores cache entries as bytes. Eviction happens when the size of
+the data container reaches 100 bytes and {brandname} gets a request to create a

@@ -0,0 +1,23 @@
+[id='expiration-{context}']
+= Expiration
+Expiration removes entries from memory when they reach one of the following
+time limits:
+
+Lifespan::
+Sets the maximum amount of time that entries can exist.
+
+Maximum idle::
+Specifies how long entries can remain idle. If operations do not occur for
+entries, they become idle.
+
+[IMPORTANT]
+====
+Maximum idle expiration does not currently support:
+
+* Entries stored in off-heap memory.
+* Cache configurations with persistent cache stores.
+
+When using maximum idle expiration with an exception-based eviction policy,
+entries that are expired by not yet removed from the cache count towards the

nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,38 @@
+[id='how_expiration_works-{context}']
+= How Expiration Works
+By default, `Cache.put()` creates immortal entries. With expiration, `Cache.put()` creates mortal entries with lifespans and maximum idle times.
+
+When you configure expiration, {brandname} stores keys with metadata that
+determines when entries expire.
+
+* Lifespan uses a `creation` timestamp and the value for the `lifespan` configuration property.
+* Maximum idle uses a `last used` timestamp and the value for the `max-idle` configuration property.
+
+{brandname} checks if lifespan or maximum idle metadata is set and then
+compares the values with the current time.
+
+If `(creation + lifespan > currentTime)` or `(lastUsed + maxIdle > currentTime)` then {brandname} detects that the entry is expired.
+
+Expiration occurs whenever entries are accessed or iterated on.

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
            expired and removes it. The `Cache.get()` call does not return.
          
          
            
            expired and removes it. The `Cache.get()` will return `null`.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,38 @@
+[id='how_expiration_works-{context}']
+= How Expiration Works
+By default, `Cache.put()` creates immortal entries. With expiration, `Cache.put()` creates mortal entries with lifespans and maximum idle times.
+
+When you configure expiration, {brandname} stores keys with metadata that
+determines when entries expire.
+
+* Lifespan uses a `creation` timestamp and the value for the `lifespan` configuration property.
+* Maximum idle uses a `last used` timestamp and the value for the `max-idle` configuration property.
+
+{brandname} checks if lifespan or maximum idle metadata is set and then
+compares the values with the current time.
+
+If `(creation + lifespan > currentTime)` or `(lastUsed + maxIdle > currentTime)` then {brandname} detects that the entry is expired.
+
+Expiration occurs whenever entries are accessed or iterated on.
+
+For example, `k1` reaches the maximum idle time and a client makes a
+`Cache.get(k1)` request. In this case, {brandname} detects that the entry is
+expired and removes it. The `Cache.get()` call does not return.

nodes.bodyText: So technically this is a bit different based on if it is a store vs a loader. Technically a loader would still load the value if it expired. The vast majority of cases are a store though.
nodes.diffHunk:

+

@@ -0,0 +1,38 @@
+[id='how_expiration_works-{context}']
+= How Expiration Works
+By default, `Cache.put()` creates immortal entries. With expiration, `Cache.put()` creates mortal entries with lifespans and maximum idle times.
+
+When you configure expiration, {brandname} stores keys with metadata that
+determines when entries expire.
+
+* Lifespan uses a `creation` timestamp and the value for the `lifespan` configuration property.
+* Maximum idle uses a `last used` timestamp and the value for the `max-idle` configuration property.
+
+{brandname} checks if lifespan or maximum idle metadata is set and then
+compares the values with the current time.
+
+If `(creation + lifespan > currentTime)` or `(lastUsed + maxIdle > currentTime)` then {brandname} detects that the entry is expired.
+
+Expiration occurs whenever entries are accessed or iterated on.
+
+For example, `k1` reaches the maximum idle time and a client makes a
+`Cache.get(k1)` request. In this case, {brandname} detects that the entry is
+expired and removes it. The `Cache.get()` call does not return.
+
+//dnaro: contradicting info here. does this apply with local cache stores only?
+{brandname} first removes entries from the data container and then from the
+cache store, if configured.
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+{brandname} adds expiration metadata as `long` primitive data types to cache entries.
+
+If you configure lifespan expiration, {brandname} adds only the corresponding
+metadata and likewise for maximum idle. If you configure both lifespan and
+maximum idle expiration, {brandname} adds all metadata to keys.
+
+`long` primitive data types are eight bytes in size. If you configure either

nodes.bodyText: We don't remove those objects as part of the iteration. This is still only done on access, ie. Cache#get, or from the reaper.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,32 @@
+[id='maxidle_expiration-{context}']
+= Maximum Idle and Clustered Caches
+Because maximum idle expiration relies on the last access time for cache
+entries, it has some limitations with clustered cache modes.
+
+With lifespan expiration, the creation time for cache entries provides a value
+that is consistent across clustered caches. For example, the creation time for
+`k1` is always the same on all nodes.
+
+For maximum idle expiration with clustered caches, last access time for entries
+is not always the same on all nodes. To ensure that entries have the same
+relative access times across clusters, {brandname} sends touch commands to all
+owners when keys are accessed.
+
+The touch commands that {brandname} send have the following considerations:
+
+* `Cache.get()` requests do not return until all touch commands complete. This synchronous behavior increases latency of client requests.
+* The touch command also updates the "recently accessed" metadata for cache entries on all owners, which {brandname} uses for eviction.
+//Scattered cache is community only
+ifndef::productized[]
+* With scattered cache mode, {brandname} sends touch commands to all nodes, not
+just primary and backup owners.
+endif::productized[]
+
+[NOTE]
+====
+Iteration across a clustered cache can return expired entries that have
+exceeded the maximum idle time limit. This behavior ensures performance because 
+no remote invocations are performed during the iteration. However this behavior
+does not refresh any expired entries, which are removed after the iteration

nodes.bodyText: We may want to mention that currently you cannot disable the expiration reaper when a store is in use.
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,24 @@
+[id='expiration_reaper-{context}']
+= Expiration Reaper
+{brandname} uses a reaper thread that runs periodically to detect and remove
+expired entries. The expiration reaper ensures that expired entries that are no
+longer accessed are removed.
+
+The {brandname} `ExpirationManager` interface handles the expiration reaper and
+exposes the `processExpiration()` method.
+
+In some cases, you can disable the expiration reaper and manually expire
+entries by calling `processExpiration()`; for instance, if you are using local
+cache mode with a custom application where a maintenance thread runs
+periodically.
+
+[IMPORTANT]
+====
+If you use clustered cache modes or cache stores, you should never disable the
